intro: Brassica oleracea var. micropodium, commonly known as the cauliflower, is a flowering plant in the Brassicaceae family. It is characterized by its dense, compact inflorescence composed of undeveloped flower buds, known as curds. The plant typically grows to a height of 40–100 cm and has dark green, lobed leaves. It thrives in cool climates and is cultivated for its edible curds, which are used in various culinary dishes. The plant is closely related to other cruciferous vegetables like broccoli and cabbage.
